articles.headline: A Vision Beyond Cable for Comcast After Merger
articles.snippet: If its acquisition of Time Warner Cable is approved, Comcast will become much more than a regional cable company, says its chief executive, Brian Roberts.
articles.abstract: If its acquisition of Time Warner Cable is approved, Comcast will become much more than a regional cable company, says its chief executive, Brian Roberts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Comcast’s chief executive, Brian Roberts, was stung four years ago when Reed Hastings, chief executive of the then-fledgling Netflix, dismissed Comcast with a rhetorical question: “Why would we want to do a deal with a regional cable company?”

articles.headline: Navigating the Logistics of Death Ahead of Time
articles.snippet: The number of end-of-life planning and document storage sites is on the rise.
articles.abstract: The number of end-of-life planning and document storage sites is on the rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Abby Schneiderman, then a 32-year-old mother and entrepreneur, was getting ready to celebrate her daughter’s first birthday when she received the news: Her older brother had been killed in a head-on collision while driving through East Hampton, N.Y., with his family.

articles.headline: G.M. Expands Ignition Switch Recall to Later Models
articles.snippet: The move adds 971,000 small cars worldwide, including 824,000 in the United States, that may have been previously repaired with faulty switches.
articles.abstract: The move adds 971,000 small cars worldwide, including 824,000 in the United States, that may have been previously repaired with faulty switches.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Friday that it was expanding its ignition switch recall to include an additional 971,000 small cars worldwide that may have been previously repaired with defective switches.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Putin Calls Obama to Discuss Ukraine, White House Says
articles.snippet: In a phone call initiated by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, President Obama told Mr. Putin that the United States would like to see Russia pull back its troops from Crimea and not take any further steps into Ukraine.
articles.abstract: In a phone call initiated by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, President Obama told Mr. Putin that the United States would like to see Russia pull back its troops from Crimea and not take any further steps into Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia reached out to President Obama on Friday to discuss ideas about how to peacefully resolve the international standoff over Ukraine, a surprise move by Moscow to pull back from the brink of an escalated confrontation that has put Europe and much of the world on edge.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Michael D. Shear and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Women Charge Bias and Harassment in Suit Against Sterling Jewelers
articles.snippet: A group of 12 women said they were paid less than men and were sexually harassed while working for the company’s stores, Jared and Kay Jewelers.
articles.abstract: A group of 12 women said they were paid less than men and were sexually harassed while working for the company’s stores, Jared and Kay Jewelers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among glittering diamonds and shining gemstones, Dawn Souto-Coons loved being in what she called “the business of romance,” selling engagement rings to smiling couples at a Jared jewelry store in Florida.

articles.headline: Start-Up Health Insurer Finds Foothold in New York
articles.snippet: Oscar is Silicon Alley’s challenge to the staid business of health insurance and is trying to use its tech-world skills to provide an easier experience to consumers.
articles.abstract: Oscar is Silicon Alley’s challenge to the staid business of health insurance and is trying to use its tech-world skills to provide an easier experience to consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: One afternoon in late March, Kevin Nazemi stood along a wall of the small, sweltering offices of the health insurance start-up Oscar in downtown New York, trying to rally the troops.

articles.headline: An Engineer’s Eureka Moment With a G.M. Flaw
articles.snippet: A $30 replacement part helped set in motion General Motors’ recall of 2.6 million Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars, and one of the gravest safety crises in company history.
articles.abstract: A $30 replacement part helped set in motion General Motors’ recall of 2.6 million Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars, and one of the gravest safety crises in company history.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Somewhere inside the two-inch ignition switch from the 2005 Chevrolet Cobalt was the clue that Mark Hood was seeking.

articles.headline: The Mines Have Shut Down. The Miners Haven’t.
articles.snippet: Industrial coal mines of Lower Silesia, Poland, closed in the late 1990s, but the mining has continued in a more secret and dangerous form.
articles.abstract: Industrial coal mines of Lower Silesia, Poland, closed in the late 1990s, but the mining has continued in a more secret and dangerous form.
articles.lead_paragraph: Down a homemade mine shaft in southwestern Poland, a would-be comedian sang in the faint glowing light.

articles.headline: Warner’s C.E.O. Is Bullish on the Big Screen
articles.snippet: In Hollywood’s sea of bravado, Kevin Tsujihara, the quiet new chief executive of Warner Bros., may seem miscast. But he is already making bold bets to keep the studio on top.
articles.abstract: In Hollywood’s sea of bravado, Kevin Tsujihara, the quiet new chief executive of Warner Bros., may seem miscast. But he is already making bold bets to keep the studio on top.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a quiet and courteous DVD executive named Kevin Tsujihara ascended to the Warner Bros. throne last year, Hollywood did not know quite what to make of him.

articles.headline: A Lone Ranger of the 401(k)’s
articles.snippet: A lawyer’s string of cases highlights a corporate responsibility to monitor the costs and fees in employees’ retirement plans.
articles.abstract: A lawyer’s string of cases highlights a corporate responsibility to monitor the costs and fees in employees’ retirement plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The arithmetic could not be simpler. The more fees you pay in your 401(k) plan, the less cash you’ll have for retirement.

articles.headline: Found in Mud: Precious Links to Loved Ones
articles.snippet: After a disaster that has left so many missing, ordinary objects have become connections to loved ones.
articles.abstract: After a disaster that has left so many missing, ordinary objects have become connections to loved ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARRINGTON, Wash. — Gently, Dayn Brunner reached into the mangled car and lifted his younger sister’s lifeless body out of the driver’s seat and onto a waiting tarp. For almost a week, he and his teenage sons had slogged through the muddy catacomb of what had once been a neighborhood, scouring the pulped homes and broken earth for some sign of her. Now, it was time to say goodbye and wait for the helicopter to take her away.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Kirk Johnson and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: New G.O.P. Bid to Limit Voting in Swing States
articles.snippet: Already, nine states, under Republican control, have passed measures making it harder to vote since the beginning of 2013.
articles.abstract: Already, nine states, under Republican control, have passed measures making it harder to vote since the beginning of 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Pivotal swing states under Republican control are embracing significant new electoral restrictions on registering and voting that go beyond the voter identification requirements that have caused fierce partisan brawls.
articles.byline: By Steven Yaccino and Lizette Alvarez

articles.headline: Remaking a Life, After Years in an Israeli Prison
articles.snippet: Demonized as terrorists by Israelis and lionized as freedom fighters by Palestinians, prisoners like Muqdad Salah have become a flash point in the troubled peace talks.
articles.abstract: Demonized as terrorists by Israelis and lionized as freedom fighters by Palestinians, prisoners like Muqdad Salah have become a flash point in the troubled peace talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURQA, West Bank — Muqdad Salah is a man in a hurry.

articles.headline: U.S. Agency Knew About G.M. Flaw but Did Not Act
articles.snippet: A House subcommittee will open hearings on Tuesday looking into why federal investigators never realized there was a problem with certain G.M. ignition systems.
articles.abstract: A House subcommittee will open hearings on Tuesday looking into why federal investigators never realized there was a problem with certain G.M. ignition systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators decided not to open an inquiry on the ignitions of Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars even after their own investigators reported in 2007 that they knew of four fatal crashes, 29 complaints and 14 other reports that showed the problem disabled air bags, according to a memo released by a House subcommittee on Sunday.

articles.headline: Hopes Frustrated, Many Latinos Reject the Ballot Box Altogether
articles.snippet: Across the country, immigrant-rights advocates report disillusionment with both parties among Latinos, enough to threaten recent gains in voting participation that have reshaped politics to Democrats’ advantage nationally.
articles.abstract: Across the country, immigrant-rights advocates report disillusionment with both parties among Latinos, enough to threaten recent gains in voting participation that have reshaped politics to Democrats’ advantage nationally.
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — As the weather warms, Lizeth Chacon is anticipating a new season of registering Latino voters — yet dreading experiences like one late last year, when she came upon a skate park full of older teenagers.

articles.headline: In Media Moguls’ Rarefied Realm, It’s Like Father, Like Son
articles.snippet: Even a cursory look at the media landscape suggests Rupert Murdoch is far from an outlier in wanting to see a property he built with his bare-knuckled hands land on his progeny.
articles.abstract: Even a cursory look at the media landscape suggests Rupert Murdoch is far from an outlier in wanting to see a property he built with his bare-knuckled hands land on his progeny.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, Rupert Murdoch handed the future leadership of two publicly held companies worth a combined $80 billion to his two sons, almost as casually as if they were the keys to the family station wagon.

articles.headline: WWE Network Is Loud Introduction to the Video Streaming Ring
articles.snippet: World Wrestling Entertainment has positioned itself on the cutting edge of Internet television with its new subscription-only streaming video service.
articles.abstract: World Wrestling Entertainment has positioned itself on the cutting edge of Internet television with its new subscription-only streaming video service.
articles.lead_paragraph: When listing the visionary media moguls of the digital age, Vince McMahon, the professional wrestling impresario, might not immediately come to mind.

articles.headline: Hollywood’s Antipiracy Efforts Add New Voice
articles.snippet: Ruth Vitale, an independent film executive, was recently named executive director of CreativeFuture, a new force in the copyright wars.
articles.abstract: Ruth Vitale, an independent film executive, was recently named executive director of CreativeFuture, a new force in the copyright wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the fall of 2012, Ruth Vitale, a sassy independent film executive, nosed her horse into a badly directed jump and crashed in the mud.

articles.headline: Apple’s War on Samsung Has Google in Crossfire
articles.snippet: Apple is seeking about $2 billion in damages from Samsung, which in turn says Apple violated its patents, but the case could also have major implications for Google.
articles.abstract: Apple is seeking about $2 billion in damages from Samsung, which in turn says Apple violated its patents, but the case could also have major implications for Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Officially, it’s Apple versus Samsung Electronics in another tech patent face-off in a San Jose courtroom this week. But there is another company with a lot at stake in the case — Google.

articles.headline: Carmakers’ Close Ties to Regulator Scrutinized
articles.snippet: Questions are once again being raised about “an all-too-cozy relationship” between former National Highway Traffic Safety Administration officials and the automobile industry.
articles.abstract: Questions are once again being raised about “an all-too-cozy relationship” between former National Highway Traffic Safety Administration officials and the automobile industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was nothing unusual about a letter with Jacqueline S. Glassman’s name on it discussing life-threatening safety defects and requiring more information from a manufacturer; Ms. Glassman was once chief counsel of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, then deputy administrator, and, briefly, acting administrator.
articles.byline: By Christopher Jensen and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: A Borderline Where Women Bear the Weight
articles.snippet: Morocco’s “mule ladies” haul goods into the country from Spain, earning as little as three euros per trip. As hard times push men toward these jobs, the working conditions have become dangerous.
articles.abstract: Morocco’s “mule ladies” haul goods into the country from Spain, earning as little as three euros per trip. As hard times push men toward these jobs, the working conditions have become dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: MELILLA, Spain — It was 9 a.m., and hundreds of Moroccan women, many of them older, were already at work, bent over and straining, trying to inch up the hill to the border post here. Many had bundles as big as washing machines lashed to their backs.

articles.headline: In New Health Care Era, Blessings and Hurdles
articles.snippet: Millions have gained coverage through private plans and expanded Medicaid, but costs still hinder some, and many providers are struggling to adjust to an influx of patients.
articles.abstract: Millions have gained coverage through private plans and expanded Medicaid, but costs still hinder some, and many providers are struggling to adjust to an influx of patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — In a plain brown health clinic on a busy boulevard here, the growing pains of the Affordable Care Act are already being felt — almost too sharply for the harried staff trying to keep up with the flow of patients.

articles.headline: Yellen Says Fed Is Determined to Improve the Labor Market
articles.snippet: Ms. Yellen’s speech offered a strong reminder of her concern about unemployment, and a rebuttal to economists who fault the Fed’s ability to improve labor conditions.
articles.abstract: Ms. Yellen’s speech offered a strong reminder of her concern about unemployment, and a rebuttal to economists who fault the Fed’s ability to improve labor conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Janet L. Yellen, the new Federal Reserve chairwoman, devoted more than an hour last week talking by telephone with three Chicago-area residents struggling to find jobs.
